newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel, PLO restart Hebron talks.
newsitem.headline: Israel, PLO restart Hebron talks.

text.p: Israel and the PLO restarted U.S.-brokered talks on Thursday on implementing a long-delayed Israeli troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.

"Progress has been made but there are still some differences that both sides are trying to overcome," U.S. mediator Dennis Ross told Reuters as negotiators began a session in a Jerusalem hotel likely to run into the early hours of Friday.
"The closer you get, some problems come up that are not anticipated but it's part of the overall process. I feel there is a genuine effort to reach agreement and I am hopeful," he said.
PLO officials said Palestinian negotiators submitted on Wednesday a paper listing all the points of agreement and contention between the two sides in the talks that have staggered on for weeks.

The PLO said the main sticking point was Israel's insistence on "hot pursuit" of Arab guerrillas into what would be Palestinian-controlled areas of Hebron and its objection, on security grounds, to the reopening of a road in the town centre.

Israel handed over other West Bank towns to Palestinian rule under a 1995 peace deal but delayed a pullback from Hebron, home to 400 Jewish settlers and 100,000 Arabs, after a spree of suicide bombings in February and March.
Palestinians view a partial pullback from Hebron as a litmus test of right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's pledge to pursue peace efforts begun by the former centre-left Israeli government.
Netanyahu opposes the former administration's policy of returning occupied Arab land for peace.
Near Tel Aviv, police shot and wounded a Palestinian, saying he fled a security checkpoint set up to prevent anti-Israeli attacks to mark an Islamic leader's assassination.

When police at the Morasha junction discovered that the man, one of five Palestinian workers in a van, had forged identity papers, he fled for a field and refused their order to stop, they said. Police shot and seriously wounded him.
Israel was on high security alert ahead of the October 26 anniversary of the killing of Fathi Shqaqi, leader of the militant Islamic Jihad group behind suicide attacks in Israel.
Shqaqi was gunned down in Malta last year in what Palestinians believe was an attack by Israel's Mossad secret service. The militant group vowed to avenge his murder.

Israel set up roadblocks to enforce a closure imposed on the West Bank and Gaza Strip for fear of suicide attacks. Palestinians assail the closure as a collective punishment denying their workers jobs in the Jewish state.
